ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: So many different ways of viewing medicine and the ethical/philosophical issues that come with it. Dr. Morrison is the absolute best. He gives so much feedback and really want s his students to learn. So much reading i was never exposed to etc etc

I learned a ton about the relationship between medicine and humanities, which is a deeper relationship than I could have imagined. I also got to explore many beautiful texts regarding the nature of reason, science and a meaningful life.

Relevance of the humanities in clinical medicine; Aristotelianism vs. Platonism; cognitive biases; the limits of reason; the importance of narrative and uncertainty in medicine; core authors and texts that inform the medical humanities

I learned how to connect pieces of literature to medicine. This class gave valuable insight into different thinkers, writers, and medical experts. It explores the humanistic side of medicine that often goes overlooked.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: Dr. Morrison -- his lectures at the beginning, our visits outside of the classroom, the most positive learning environment, class discussions, readings

Weaknesses: sometimes readings were tough, wish we got a little more background before diving in

I think the course was run extremely well! The nature of the course is that we cannot go too, too in depth on anything, but I thought the move from specifically medicine related texts earlier on to more philosophical texts later was great.

Strengths: Dr. Morrison's enthusiasm about the material and his care for students; the balance of readings that span philosophy, literature, and clinically-focused physicians' experiences; field trips to the Marsh Botanical Garden, libraries, and museums; Dr. Morrison's personal anecdotes from clinical practice.
Weaknesses: not enough time given for group discussion of the readings; discussion sometimes felt like a back-and-forth between students and Dr. Morrison rather than an organic development of each other's ideas; more guidance on the writing assignments would also have been helpful.

This course was wonderful, and I looked forward to every classwhich I really can't say about many other courses I've taken. The majority of students were pre-med, but I think it's a good class to take even if you're not. The class (a seminar) was more or less structured as follows: Dr. Morrison lectured for the first 2/3s of each class, and the latter 1/3 of each class was a group discussion. Dr. Morrison is a great lecturer so I didn't mind this, but I do think this structure could be amended to make class even more engagingand to take greater advantage of the seminar format. For instance, the lecture could be interspersed with discussion. Ie. the lecture could take up the whole class, but students would share their thoughts throughout. On the whole though, the course was awesome. I especially appreciated the many field trips.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: 100% if you are interested in the intersection between medicine and the humanitiies

I would certainly recommend this course! Its a lovely introduction to one of the more fascinating subjects you can explore at a university. Whether youre a humanities person or a Stem person, you can gain a lot from this class.
I would recommend this course if you are genuinely interested in both philosophy/literature and medicine.

Yes. For any student but especially for premed students. Dr. Morrison is a physician interested in implementing humanistic thought in healthcare decisions.  It brings forth a very important and necessary part of the job that may be overlooked elsewhere. The course readings are very interesting, and the guest speakers were great to hear from (ie lisa sanders, henry marsh). As a STEM major, I enjoyed writing the papers for the class.
Absolutely! Every aspiring pre-med should take this class
